issues.description: Inner-artifact contradiction in the problem statement about the type of Animal.name: the UML diagram shows the attribute as "name: String" while the textual instructions explicitly require using StringBuilder for the name attribute. This conflicting information in the problem statement can confuse students about which type they should use when implementing Animal and its constructors/getters/setters.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the problem statement internally consistent. Either (A) update the UML diagram to show name: StringBuilder (preferred, to match the textual instruction), or (B) change the textual instruction to accept String if String is intended. Clearly state whether the constructor/getter/setter should use/return a StringBuilder or a String.

issues.description: Cross-artifact type mismatch: the solution implementation defines Animal.name as a String (private String name) and the Animal constructor/getter/setter operate on String, but the problem statement explicitly requires using StringBuilder for the name attribute. This inconsistency between the specification and the provided solution/template will confuse students about the intended type and may cause them to implement code that does not match the exercise requirements.
issues.suggested_fix: Align implementation with the problem statement. Change the Animal class to store name as a StringBuilder (private StringBuilder name). Update the constructor and getter/setter accordingly. Options: (1) Make the constructor accept a StringBuilder (Animal(StringBuilder name)), or (2) accept a String and internally initialize the field with new StringBuilder(name) (convenient for students). Also update any usage sites (e.g., code that concatenates or prints the name) to call name.toString() or adjust the getter to return a String if required by tests.

issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch between specification intent and solution: the problem requires constructors that initialize all attributes and (given the textual instruction) implies the name attribute should be a StringBuilder, but the solution's Animal constructor takes a String parameter. This mismatch affects how students should design and call constructors and may lead to inconsistent implementations.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify and align the constructor signature with the chosen attribute type. If the attribute is StringBuilder, either change the constructor to accept a StringBuilder parameter or keep a String parameter but convert it inside the constructor (this is often preferable for student convenience). Update the problem statement to state the expected constructor signature (e.g., Animal(String name) that initializes a StringBuilder internally, or Animal(StringBuilder name)).
